text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- The World Bank said it has approved $24.3 million loan to Bulgaria to help finance a government's social insurance administration project.
The loan will be repayable over a period of 20 years including five years of grace and will cover 75 percent of the project's costs. @
-- Bulgaria's State Fund for Reconstruction and Development (SFRR) is expected to reschedule next week the debts of the cash-strapped National Electricity Company, SFRR officials said.
-- Bulgaria posted 9.3 billion levs trade surplus in the second quarter, National Statistics Institute preliminary figures show.

-- Bulgaria's Privatisation Agency (PA) approved the sale of a 75-percent stake in the debt-ridden Plama oil refinery, initially slated for liquidation, to Bulgaria's Euroenergy holding, PA board chairman Dimitar Stefanov said. @

-- The Supreme Court unanimously overruled the Central Electoral Commission's decision to refuse registration to the main anti-communist opposition nominees for the country's presidential elections due on October 27.
-- The Palestine terrorist Nazem Abdulah, who hijacked the Bulgarian TU-134 plane on Monday, surrendered at Oslo's airport and asked for a lawyer and political asylum.
The eight-member Bulgarian crew was released. @
-- Energy Minister Rumen Ovcharov and the World Bank's permanent representative in Sofia Alberto Mussalem discussed a $20 million grant to Bulgaria for purchasing central heating measuring equipment.
-- Bulgarian citizens will not be allowed to open foreign currency deposits in banks abroad under a currency transactions draft expected to be discussed by the parliament in September.

-- The parliament is expected today to overrule President Zhelyu Zhelev's veto on the Radio and Television Law after the socialist-dominated media committee proposed that the bill should not be changed.

-- The International Monetary Fund (IMF) urged Bulgaria to build public confidence in local troubled banks by stabilising them and to boost tax collection, IMF's mission head Anne McGuirk said after a two-week stay in Bulgaria. @
-- The Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) is expected today to discuss the implementation of commercial banks' short-term stabilisation programmes agreed with the BNB.
